Hay dos actualizaciones en nuestro servicio de comidas a partir del lunes 21 de septiembre:

1. Debido a la participación muy baja, las comidas ya no se entregarán en los siguientes sitios a partir del lunes 21 de septiembre:
-Faith & Family Church
-AmptHill Presbyterian
-Chesterfield Volunteer Rescue Squad
-Open Door Baptist
-Belvedere Apartments
-IronBridge Church

Consulte las imágenes adjuntas para ver los sitios de distribución de comidas o visite https://mychesterfieldschools.com/

-Faith & Family Church
-AmptHill Presbyterian

post_text:
Who says virtual school can't have engaging guest speakers? Mr. Dunn, the Career Investigations teacher at Academy 360, had 50 eighth graders join his virtual meeting this morning to learn more about the rule of law and various careers in the field of law.

Thank you to our John Marshall Foundation volunteers, the Honorable Lucretia A. Carrico, Debra J. Prillaman, Esquire, and Cheryl Grissom Ragsdale, Esquire, for sharing your experience and expertise with our students!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Is your child having Chromebook problems?
The Chromebook Helpdesk is open today (Tues., Sept. 15) from 3-4:30 p.m. at Meadowbrook High (4901 Cogbill Road) to support students who need Chromebook repairs.

Need Chromebook support on any of these topics?
→ Student usernames/ passwords
→ Learning applications
→ Fixing connection issues
→ Chromebook shortcuts
→ Chromebook usage (ex: how to "right click" or how to use "caps lock")

Visit the Parent Resource Hub at bit.ly/CCPS-ParentResourceHub for help on these topics!

Can't get to the Chromebook helpdesk today? Here are the other days, times and locations they're available for support this week:

Wednesday, Sept. 16
→ 8-9:30 a.m. at Matoaca High (17700 Longhouse Lane)
→ 5-6:30 p.m. at Monacan High (11501 Smoketree Drive)

Thursday, Sept. 17
→ 8-9:30 a.m. at Matoaca High (17700 Longhouse Lane)
→ 3-4:30 p.m. at L.C. Bird High (10301 Courthouse Road)

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

Navigating the first week of virtual school had its ups and downs; however, these Crestwood Elementary School, Richmond, VA students are excited to be back in school!

These little Monarchs are thankful for fun lessons, virtually visiting with their classmates, and learning new things with their amazing teachers. We are grateful that we have such creative and kind teachers!

We'd also like to give a shout out to the Crestwood Elementarty PTA for putting this cute video together for their teachers!
#ThankYou #KindnessMatters #oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
In case you missed it...
Join us on Facebook Live for part four in our Standing Together series. On Wed., Sept. 16, from 6- 7:30 p.m., we'll be hosting Courageous Conversations: The State of Race in CCPS- Where We Are and Where We Must Go.

Our panel will explore the “state of race” in CCPS. Panelists will frankly discuss where we are as a school division around issues of race and where we must go in order to ensure equity for all stakeholders.

We will be streaming this conversation on Facebook Live and on our YouTube channel (CCPSVA).

Submit your questions prior to the Live event here: bit.ly/CCPSStandingTogether4
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
In case you missed it...
Chesterfield County Public Schools launched a live Technology Help Desk on Friday, providing an additional layer of support for Chesterfield County students and families needing assistance with Chromebooks, Canvas, the my.ccpsnet.net learning dashboard, and resetting passwords.

The Technology Help Desk is open from 7:30 a.m.-3 p.m. and 5-8 p.m. Chesterfield County Public Schools families can call 804-639-8689 for support. Support is available in other languages as well.

Team Chesterfield staff members will be available to answer questions about the school division’s virtual learning tools, provide support for navigating the school division’s learning management system (Canvas), and connect families to resources that will best support their technology needs.

For the full update, please visit https://mychesterfieldschools.com/
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Chesterfield County Prevention Services, in conjunction with the Chesterfield County Public Schools Office of Family Engagement, is offering five virtual training opportunities for Youth Mental Health First Aid Training. The curriculum, provided by the National Council of Behavioral Health, is designed for adults who work with youth and gives them the skills needed to reach out and provide initial support to children and adolescents (ages 6-18) who may be developing a mental health or substance use problem and help connect them to the appropriate care. The certified training and course are approximately six hours.

This training is designed for teachers, school staff, coaches, counselors, parents, and people who work with youth. Class sizes are limited. Please register through Eventbrite two weeks prior to the event. The event leaders will send attendees a pre-assessment and required reading one week prior to the event, that will take two hours to complete.

Register at: bit.ly/CCPSYouthMentalHealthFirstAid
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
We are aware of an issue limiting capacity on our network at this moment. This is preventing some students from successfully logging onto their morning class. We are working to address the issue with our server provider and hope to have a resolution shortly. We will keep you updated. We apologize greatly for the inconvenience.

————————————-

Somos conscientes de un problema que limita la capacidad de nuestra red en este momento. Esto impide que algunos estudiantes inicien sesión correctamente en su clase de la mañana.

Estamos trabajando rápidamente para abordar el problema con nuestro proveedor de servidor,
y espero tener una resolución en breve.

Le mantendremos informado. Nos disculpamos enormemente por las molestias.

post_text:
Our students may be starting school virtually this year, but it's still important to make sure your child is up-to-date on their immunizations.

We want our students back in our school buildings as soon as the Superintendent's public health panel says it is safe to return to in-person instruction. When that time comes, your child's immunization records must be current.

Don’t Wait, Vaccinate!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #ChesterfieldStrong
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Virginia Government
August 28 at 10:30 AM ·

Even if your child is starting school virtually, they still need to be up-to-date on their immunizations. Don’t Wait, Vaccinate! Help protect your child from preventable diseases by scheduling a free immunization appointment at one of the Chesterfield Health District locations or participating partners. More information available at https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/chesterfield/.

post_text:
We are excited for the 2020-21 school year to start this week! To help our families prepare for a successful start to an all-virtual learning environment on Sept. 8, we are sharing 10 tips for Virtual Learning Success.

Tip 9: Set clear expectations
When possible, families should build time into their day to support
their child's learning. This can be during the virtual school day or
later in the afternoon/night. Working together, we can continue to
nurture strong study habits and develop routines that best meet
student needs and family schedules.

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #ChesterfieldStrong

post_text:
As we shared earlier this week, the USDA has decided to extend its Summer Food Service Program and Seamless Summer Option, including flexibilities allowed during the coronavirus pandemic, through Dec. 31 or whenever available funding runs out.

To meet the needs of children who are in a virtual learning setting, Chesterfield County Public Schools will continue to provide meals for children for pick-up without charge and regardless of race, color, national origin, sex, age or disability and without discrimination. Meals will be provided on a first-come, first-served basis at the sites and times listed below.

Updates from this week’s message:
• Under the USDA plan, Chesterfield County children ages 2-18 are eligible to receive free meals starting Sept. 8.
• Pre-orders no longer will be required.
• Offsite distribution sites now will be open starting Wednesday, Sept. 9 instead of Thursday, Sept. 10.

See the attached images for times and locations.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
We are excited for the 2020-21 school year to start next week!

To help our families prepare for a successful start to an all-virtual learning environment on Sept. 8, we will be sharing 10 tips for Virtual Learning Success over the next five days.

Tip 1: Understand your role
You are not expected to take the place of your child's teachers. You are a support role to help keep your child engaged and thinking critically.

It's important for children to learn how to problem solve and advocate for themselves. Encourage your child to reach out to their teachers if they find that they are not fully understanding concepts. (Depending on the age of the child, parents may need to assist them.)
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

Our students may be starting school virtually this year, but it's still important to make sure your child is up-to-date on their immunizations.

We want our students back in our school buildings as soon as the Superintendent's public health panel says it is safe to return to in-person instruction. When that time comes, your child's immunization records must be current.

Don’t Wait, Vaccinate!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #ChesterfieldStrong

Even if your child is starting school virtually, they still need to be up-to-date on their immunizations. Don’t Wait, Vaccinate! post_text:
Did you know that not all virtual learning is done on a computer? Teachers frequently have students participate in activities that make learning more tangible. For example, instead of having students complete a worksheet on math concepts, they may use counters and manipulatives such as beads or pom poms or cereal to make learning more hands-on and meaningful.

Consider purchasing supplies or make a donation to help Chesterfield County students experience success while in a virtual learning environment! #oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

Amazon Wish List: bit.ly/CCPS-VirtualSupplyWishList

CEF Emergency Response Fund: bit.ly/CEF-EmergencyResponseFund

Three more school replacement construction projects approved by Chesterfield County residents through the 2013 school bond referendum will wrap up this fall.

New replacement buildings for Harrowgate Elementary, Matoaca Elementary and Manchester Middle are part of a strategic investment initiated by previous School Boards that will allow for more equitable and safer schools across the school division.

To read more about the upcoming Virtual Ribbon-Cutting Ceremonies for these three new schools, visit bit.ly/CCPSVirtualRibbonCutting

post_text: Important update from Chesterfield County Virginia Government.
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Virginia Government
August 16 at 11:55 PM ·

Chesterfield County has declared emergency water restrictions for all its water customers.

Customers are asked to conserve water for essential use only and immediately stop all irrigation. While emergency restrictions are in place to help reduce demand on the water system, the water is safe to drink.

Click on the link for more information: https://www.chesterfield.gov/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=1540

post_text: Important!
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Police
August 15 at 6:31 PM ·

Alert:
Chesterfield County Police and Chesterfield Fire & EMS are starting evacuations of residences downstream from the Falling Creek Dam off Hopkins Road.
As of 5:45 p.m., the water level was over 100 feet, which is a stage three flood advisory for that dam.
Meadowbrook High School will open at 7 p.m. as a shelter for and the Chesterfield County Animal Shelter will open to accept pets from those who are being actively evacuated by Chesterfield Police and Fire & EMS. These shelters are not open for the general public.
Residents are reminded that shelter capacity has been greatly reduced due to the ongoing COVID-19 situation. Residents who come to the shelter should bring their own masks, pillows, blankets, medication, personal hygiene items, change of clothes and device chargers.

post_text:
Luke F., a senior at Monacan High and a Boy Scout with Troop 1829, recently created an outdoor drama and celebration venue for students at Falling Creek Middle School.

Luke began the Eagle Scout project conversation of connecting students with the arts through a proposal for a stage with Communities In Schools of Chesterfield site coordinator, Kimberly Reynolds. More than a year later, he presented his final project to the school this week. Luke designed the stage to be mobile so that it can be reconfigured to accommodate drama, music, award ceremonies and future family engagement events.

Luke also donated a check for $200 to Communities In Schools of Chesterfield for any future maintenance or activities to support his project.

Thank you, Luke, for your dedication, your vision and for your desire that all students should have access to the arts. Your project will impact students and families for many years to come!

post_text:
Join us! We will be hosting our third Standing Together series event, Courageous Conversations: Recruiting & Retaining Teachers of Color & Why It’s Important on Wed., Aug. 12, from 6-7:30 p.m.

Our event moderator will be Anthony Antoine, and the event panel will include:

~ Dr. Andrew Daire, Ph.D. Dean & Professor, School of Education
~ Dr. Bruce Fillman, Principal Hening Elementary School
~ Kim Hough, Director of Human Resources CCPS
~ Dr. Maia Johnson, Coordinator of Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion
~ Ms. Jessica Monroe, Teacher Bellwood Elementary School
~ Mrs. Noriko Wade, Parent, CCPS
~ Dr. Tinkhani White, Director of School Improvement

Community members are encouraged to share questions in advance and offer potential topics for subsequent conversations: bit.ly/CCPSStandingTogether3
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong
text:
Join us! We will be hosting our third Standing Together series event, Courageous Conversations: Recruiting & Retaining Teachers of Color & Why It’s Important on Wed., Aug. 12, from 6-7:30 p.m.

Our event moderator will be Anthony Antoine, and the event panel will include:

~ Dr. Andrew Daire, Ph.D. Dean & Professor, School of Education
~ Dr. Bruce Fillman, Principal Hening Elementary School
~ Kim Hough, Director of Human Resources CCPS
~ Dr. Maia Johnson, Coordinator of Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion
~ Ms. Jessica Monroe, Teacher Bellwood Elementary School
~ Mrs. Noriko Wade, Parent, CCPS
~ Dr. Tinkhani White, Director of School Improvement

Community members are encouraged to share questions in advance and offer potential topics for subsequent conversations: bit.ly/CCPSStandingTogether3
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Ms. Stiebeling's third-graders at Harrowgate Elementary successfully completed their community service project by surpassing their goal of 50 pounds of pop tops this past spring.

Even though the school building closed in March, the students at Harrowgate collected 68.67 pounds of pop tops, which were then donated to The Ronald McDonald House Charities of Richmond.

This was 26 more pounds than they collected two years ago. Way to go, Eagles! We're proud of you for making a difference in our community!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #KindnessMatters

The Virginia Technology and Engineering Education Association (VTEEA) announced this week that two #oneCCPS teachers are recipients of awards this year!

Laura Prymak, a PreK STEAM Resource Teacher at Winterpock Elementary,
received the 2020 Elementary Teacher of the Year for Technology and Engineering Award.

Jay Wright, Tech-ED Teacher at Manchester Middle School, is the 2020 Middle School Program of the Year Award recipient.

Congratulations, Laura and Jay! Thank you for encouraging and inspiring our students to be creative problem solvers and critical thinkers!

post_text:
For the safety of our staff members, Tuesday, Aug. 4 will be a telework day for all school division staff members regularly scheduled to report to work. Schools and school division offices will be closed.

Per School Board policy, employees who are required to work during closings for facility protection, clean up, and maintenance should be prepared Tuesday afternoon to check on their school facility and prepare for a Wednesday reopening.

Registration appointments, Chromebook distribution opportunities and other meetings scheduled to be held at a school or school division office will be rescheduled.

We apologize for any inconvenience.

post_text:
Since the School Board’s decision last week to begin the 2020-21 school year in a virtual learning environment, Chesterfield County Public Schools has been working to finalize plans to provide high-quality levels of support to students, their families, and our staff members.

It is the school division’s intention to return to an in-person learning environment once scientific data and public health metrics illustrate it is safe to do so. That could come at any time during the school year.

We realize that families and students need more information prior to deciding whether they would want their child to return to an in-person learning environment or commit to remaining in a virtual learning environment.

To learn about Project Restart- Plan to Return, visit https://mychesterfieldschools.com/docs/overview/

To read the entire article, visit: https://mychesterfieldschools.com/school-board-approves-virtual-start-to-2020-21-school-year/

post_text:
Las Escuelas Públicas del Condado de Chesterfield organizarán una reunión comunitaria virtual con las familias de habla hispana de la división escolar el martes 14 de julio a las 5:30 p.m. para discutir posibles opciones para comenzar el año escolar 2020-21. La reunión se transmitirá en vivo en el sitio web de la división escolar, el canal de YouTube de la división escolar y la página de Facebook de la división escolar; un enlace a la transmisión en vivo también estará disponible a través de la cuenta de Twitter de la división escolar. Se aceptarán comentarios y preguntas en español por adelantado y a través de las funciones de chat en vivo.

La comunidad de habla hispana y los miembros del personal están invitados a asistir a la reunión virtual del ayuntamiento de 90 minutos. Los intérpretes traducirán durante todo el evento y supervisarán los comentarios en las funciones de chat en vivo de las redes sociales, para que las preguntas se puedan abordar en tiempo real.

Visita nuestro sitio web para más detalles.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong
shared_text:
MYCHESTERFIELDSCHOOLS.COM
Reunión de la comunidad virtual programada para familias de habla hispana para discutir opciones para la reapertura de escuelas | Chesterfield County Public Schools
text:
Las Escuelas Públicas del Condado de Chesterfield organizarán una reunión comunitaria virtual con las familias de habla hispana de la división escolar el martes 14 de julio a las 5:30 p.m. para discutir posibles opciones para comenzar el año escolar 2020-21. La reunión se transmitirá en vivo en el sitio web de la división escolar, el canal de YouTube de la división escolar y la página de Facebook de la división escolar; un enlace a la transmisión en vivo también estará disponible a través de la cuenta de Twitter de la división escolar. Se aceptarán comentarios y preguntas en español por adelantado y a través de las funciones de chat en vivo.

La comunidad de habla hispana y los miembros del personal están invitados a asistir a la reunión virtual del ayuntamiento de 90 minutos. Los intérpretes traducirán durante todo el evento y supervisarán los comentarios en las funciones de chat en vivo de las redes sociales, para que las preguntas se puedan abordar en tiempo real.

Visita nuestro sitio web para más detalles.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

MYCHESTERFIELDSCHOOLS.COM
Reunión de la comunidad virtual programada para familias de habla hispana para discutir opciones para la reapertura de escuelas | Chesterfield County Public Schools

post_text:
A few weeks ago, we shared that the #oneCCPS Going For Gold summer reading challenge was available for our elementary students to read and participate in activities that would win their team points.

We tallied the minutes read for the first three weeks of Going For Gold, and right now Team Green- "Pursue Excellence" is in the lead CLOSELY followed by Team Red-"Respect Others!"

Stay tuned for updates and prizes in the upcoming weeks!

If your child hasn't gotten involved yet, it's not too late to join in the reading fun! Learn more here: mychesterfieldschools.com/going-for-gold/

post_text:
En caso que te lo hayas perdido:
Las Escuelas Públicas del Condado de Chesterfield comenzarán la inscripción presencial en kínder para la Promoción 2033 en las escuelas base de los estudiantes a partir de esta semana con cita previa.

Las familias de los estudiantes ingresantes en kínder que ya se han preinscrito en línea o cuyo hijo participó en un programa de prekínder de Chesterfield durante el año escolar 2019-20, serán contactadas por la escuela de su hijo para concertar citas de inscripción presenciales. Todas las demás familias pueden llamar a la escuela de su hijo para concertar una cita de inscripción en kínder o completar el formulario de preinscripción en línea para ser contactados.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

In case you missed it... Chesterfield County Public Schools will begin in-person kindergarten registration for the Class of 2033 at students’ home schools beginning this week by appointment.

Families of incoming kindergarten students who have already preregistered online or whose child participated in a Chesterfield prekindergarten program during the 2019-20 school year will be contacted by their child’s school to set up in-person registration appointments. All other families can call their child’s school to schedule a kindergarten registration appointment or complete the online preregistration form in order to be contacted.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Monday, July 6, will not be a serving day as schools and offices will be closed to observe Independence Day. Thursday, July 3, we will serve five days’ meals, and Tuesday, July 7, we will serve two days’ meals. We will resume regular serving days Thursday, July 9.

Update for meal distribution sites July 1- August 31: Due to the USDA not extending the waiver past June 30, 2020, snack and supper will no longer be served beginning July 1.
--------------------------------------------------------------------

El lunes 6 de julio no será un día de servicio ya que las escuelas y oficinas estarán cerradas para observar el Día de la Independencia. El jueves 3 de julio serviremos comidas de cinco días y el martes 7 de julio serviremos comidas de dos días. Reanudaremos los días regulares de servicio el jueves 9 de julio.

Actualización para los sitios de distribución de comidas del 1 de julio al 31 de agosto: debido a que el USDA no extiende la exención después del 30 de junio de 2020, la merienda y la cena ya no se servirán a partir del 1 de julio.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
The Chesterfield County School Board will host a series of virtual community meetings regarding potential options for reopening schools in Fall 2020. Meetings will be live streamed on the school division’s website, school division’s YouTube channel and school division’s Facebook page; a link to the live stream also will be made available via the school division’s Twitter account. Comments and questions will be accepted in advance and via live stream chat functions.

Community and staff members are invited to attend the 90-minute meeting in the magisterial district in which they live or work. Each district has three scheduled meetings, which are provided in the morning, afternoon and evening.

Please visit our website to see the full update and times.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

We've know for a while now that Mr. Smalls is awesome! He was featured in our #oneCCPS Someone You Should Know series last year. Now the rest of RVA knows him too!

shared_text:
WTVR CBS 6 News
June 24 at 8:53 PM ·

There is a link between music and math, poetry, and other subjects. The question is how do you teach music to students during the pandemic?

Spring Run Elementary music teacher Aubrey Smalls found an answer.

Logging onto his Twitter account, you’ll find lessons on music, singing, and how to build DIY instruments.

post_text:
Congratulations to the Class of 2020's Alesandra Cowardin! She was recently awarded the National Technical Honor Society's (NTHS) prestigious Jon H. Poteat Scholarship.

NTHS annually honors the achievements of top Career and Technical Education students who consistently exemplify their seven character attributes– Skill, Honesty, Service, Responsibility, Scholarship, Citizenship, and Leadership.

Alesandra's focus of studies at CTC @Hull was Occupational Physical Therapy. She is one of only 250 students nationwide to receive this scholarship. We're so proud of you, Alesandra!
#oneCCPS

post_text:
Today's School Board work session begins at 3 p.m. The work session will be held electronically in accordance with the Continuity of County Government Ordinance adopted by the Chesterfield County Board of Supervisors on March 25, 2020 and affirmed by the School Board on April 14.

Topics discussed today will include equity, budget and returning to school.

The full agenda can be found here: https://go.boarddocs.com/vsba/chesterfield/Board.nsf/Public (Click on today's meeting, then click on "view the agenda.")

The electronic work session can be accessed live via television on Comcast Channel 98 and Verizon Channel 28 or by going to http://chesterfieldschoolsva.swagit.com/live/
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Chesterfield County is currently accepting applications for the 2020-2021 Youth Citizen Board!

The Youth Citizen Board:
Engages youth around the county to participate in local government
Organizes special initiatives and events
Participates in community service projects
Provides a forum for youth related issues

This opportunity is open to juniors and seniors from all of the CCPS high schools as well as those who live in Chesterfield but attend school outside of the county or through home-school. Visit https://www.chesterfield.gov/209/Youth-Citizen-Board for more information.
#oneCCPS

post_text:
It feels like just yesterday you began your senior year at Monacan High School. Now we're only 30 minutes away from your virtual graduation!

Join us at 7 p.m. on our Facebook page, YouTube channel (bit.ly/MonacanVirtualGraduation), website, or Verizon Channel 26 or Comcast Channel 96 (available only in Chesterfield County).

We want to see how you're celebrating! Share your watch party photos and videos using #ClassOf2020CCPS or tag us in your post.
#oneCCPS

Join us at 9 a.m. on our Facebook page, YouTube channel (bit.ly/MatoacaVirtualGraduation), website, or Verizon Channel 26 or Comcast Channel 96 (available only in Chesterfield County).

We want to see how you're celebrating! Share your watch party photos and videos using #ClassOf2020CCPS or tag us in your post.
#oneCCPS

text:
Congratulations, Manchester High School graduates!

post_text:
Join us Wednesday, June 17 at 7 p.m. for the Manchester High School Virtual Graduation! The special commencement exercise can be viewed on Facebook, on our YouTube channel (@ccpsva) or by tuning in to Verizon Channel 26 or Comcast Channel 96 (available only in Chesterfield County). We look forward to celebrating with the #Classof2020CCPS!

Graduation is an annual rite of passage for high school seniors – an opportunity to celebrate 13 years’ worth of friendships, hard work and amazing academic accomplishments with family and staff members. It pains us that the extraordinary circumstances caused by COVID-19 prevent us from giving these 4,500 young people the traditional commencement ceremony…

post_text:
Join us for our first Standing Together series event: Courageous Conversations: How to Talk about Race. This event will be the first discussion in an ongoing community conversation about equity, race and other social events impacting our community, state and nation.
The intent of the first event is to focus on how to begin courageous conversations with your families and those in your community. This event is scheduled for Wednesday, June 17 from 5-6:30 p.m. on Facebook Live. Anthony Antoine from NBC 12 will serve as the moderator with panelists including:
~ Jonathan Zur, President and CEO of the Virginia Center for Inclusive Communities
~ Travis Jones, Pastor at Motivation Church
~ Marcus Leggett, Pastor at Shiloh Baptist Church
~ Tim Joyce, President and CEO of the YMCA of Greater Richmond
~ Lauren Wynne, Coordinator of School Counseling Services for CCPS
~ Jennifer Rucker, Director of Equity and Student Support Services for CCPS
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

text:
WED, JUN 17
Facebook Live- Courageous Conversations: How to Talk about Race

post_text:
Join us for our first Facebook Live event in the Standing Together series, Courageous Conversations: How to Talk about Race.

It is scheduled for Wednesday, June 17 from 5-6:30 p.m. on Facebook Live. Anthony Antoine from NBC 12 will serve as the moderator with panelists including:
• Jonathan Zur, President and CEO of the Virginia Center for Inclusive Communities
• Travis Jones, Pastor at Motivation Church
• Marcus Leggett, Pastor at Shiloh Baptist Church
• Tim Joyce, President and CEO of the YMCA of Greater Richmond
• Lauren Wynne, Coordinator of Student Counseling Services for CCPS

Community members are encouraged to share questions in advance and offer potential topics for subsequent conversations: bit.ly/ccpsstandingtogether
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
In case you missed it...
With nearly 40,000 Chromebooks being used at home by students this summer for Recovery of Learning programs, online courses or self-paced learning, Chesterfield County Public Schools will continue to provide support throughout July for school division-issued Chromebooks through July 29.

• Staff support: Mondays and Wednesdays from 9 a.m.-noon at CTC@Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road (no support will be available July 6)
• Student support: Tuesdays at Thomas Dale High (main campus), located at 3626 W. Hundred Road, from 8-10 a.m.
• Student support: Thursdays at CTC@Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road, from 2-4 p.m.

Support is open to all students who are participating in the Chromebook take-home program. A parent and/or student will need to provide their student ID number in order to adjust the school division’s inventory records.

Appropriate social distancing protocol will be followed to protect students and staff.

Support is open to all students who are participating in the Chromebook take-home program. A parent and/or student will need to provide their student ID number in order to adjust the school division’s inventory records.

post_text:
Congratulations to the Retirement Class of 2020!

Clover Hill High Dean of Students Tommy Carter has the distinction of being the retiree with the longest service to Chesterfield County Public Schools. Carter has worked with the school division for 47 years!

We are so thankful for everything that our retirees have done to support our students, schools and community! We can't wait to celebrate you as soon as we are able to get together in large groups again.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Today marks the official end of the 2019-20 school year for our 63,000 students.

It has been 59 school days since our students and staff were last together for in-person instruction, and we have missed them constantly. We truly love and care about our students and staff.

We hope you will take time to have fun this summer. Relax and enjoy (even more) time with each other.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
With nearly 40,000 Chromebooks being used at home by students this summer for Recovery of Learning programs, online courses or self-paced learning, Chesterfield County Public Schools will continue to provide support throughout July for school division-issued Chromebooks through July 29.

• Staff support: Mondays and Wednesdays from 9 a.m.-noon at CTC@Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road (no support will be available July 6)
• Student support: Tuesdays at Thomas Dale High (main campus), located at 3626 W. Hundred Road, from 8-10 a.m.
• Student support: Thursdays at CTC@Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road, from 2-4 p.m.

Support is open to all students who are participating in the Chromebook take-home program. A parent and/or student will need to provide their student ID number in order to adjust the school division’s inventory records.

Appropriate social distancing protocol will be followed to protect students and staff.

post_text:
We look forward to welcoming our approximately 63,000 students back into classrooms as quickly and as safely as possible, understanding that they learn best when in-person instruction occurs.

We also look forward to reviewing the 126 pages worth of detailed guidance that will provide specific examples of what is needed from health, safety and logistical perspectives to reopen our schools. We also will be studying carefully how these incorporate social distancing practices recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

We know that creativity in terms of school design will be needed in order to accommodate social distancing guidance, and that school will not look like it did on March 12 when we were last in classrooms.

The Virginia Department of Education has provided guidance for reopening schools, and it can be found on this page of our website:
https://mychesterfieldschools.com/guidance-for-reopening-school/
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Beginning in April, our #oneCCPS art departments joined together to gather crayons, markers, color pencils, watercolor kits, modelling clay, pencils, sharpeners and sketchbooks (over 500 pounds of them!), and put them in ziplock bags for students at our Title I schools.

Last Monday and Tuesday the bags of art supplies were delivered to 17 Title I schools, so they can distribute them to students and families. That's 900 student art packets that will bring creativity, meaning and beauty to our students and their families!

Art teachers, thank you for enriching our students' imaginations! #CCPSstrong

post_text:
We are wrapping up our Team Chesterfield's Game Changers awards next week. There is still time to nominate someone!

Game Changers are those who:

- those who step up to meet the needs of our students;
- offer support and access to resources that assist their colleagues;
- provide an extra layer of support for families outside of the classroom; and
- who generally make a positive and sometimes life-changing difference in the lives of our students, families and their colleagues.

Please let us know who we should consider for this recognition and why by simply completing this short nomination form: bit.ly/2020GameChangers

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
The Class of 2020 started receiving their high school diplomas this week, with school-based ceremonies for families. Here are a few pictures from today's ceremonies at James River, Midlothian and Monacan high schools.

Congratulations to the Class of 2020! We are so proud of you and excited for what the future holds.The lessons learned and the skills strengthened during the past 18 years will make the Class of 2020 stronger, able to tackle and overcome any challenge that lies ahead and ready to lead us into the future.

We'll be posting pictures and videos from all of our high schools throughout the week, so check our page often.

Don’t forget to join us starting June 15 for our official virtual graduations. More details and links to come!
#ClassOf2020CCPS #strongertogether

Now that the school year has come to an end, it leaves a lot of families with uncertainty about traditional summer school events and preparing their children for the next school year.

We are excited to share information about summer learning opportunities for Chesterfield County students. Participation in these Recovery of Learning opportunities is optional.

Summer Recovery of Learning information and registration for all current CCPS elementary students (pre-k through fifth grade) can be found here: bit.ly/ElementaryRecoveryOfLearning

Summer Recovery of Learning information and registration for all CCPS middle and high school students can be found here: bit.ly/SecondaryRecoveryOfLearning

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
We have the BEST Child Safety Officers around! They are kind, thoughtful, compassionate, selfless servants in our schools and in our community.

We are grateful that these inspiring individuals are encouraging, supporting and uplifting our students. Thank you for all you do!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Police
May 29 at 8:38 AM ·

We are so proud of our Child Safety Officers and the community service efforts they have taken on during this time away from work. These men and women serve a special role in both the police department and the Chesterfield County Public Schools so it’s no surprise they are showing such kindness while they are at home. Here’s just a few of them caught in action!
Chesterfield Food Bank Chesterfield County Police Chief, Col. Jeffrey S. Katz

post_text:
Recently, a former Cosby High School graduate's mother surprised two Cosby graduating seniors with scholarships in honor of her late-son's memory.

Thank you, Ms. Stoeckli, for keeping your son's legacy alive by helping students in our community. We are proud of Ethan and Eric for earning this special award and for honoring Kyle's memory by sharing his story.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
We appreciate our community partners like the Children's Museum of Richmond! Whether it's holding a community book drive or sharing learning activities that can be done at home during school closings, they are stepping up to help our students.

Right now, the Children's Museum of Richmond is holding their annual tuition raffle. Consider purchasing a ticket that will not only help support them during COVID-19 closings, but it will also give you a chance to win!

Visit https://www.childrensmuseumofrichmond.org/community/tuition-raffle/ for details and tickets.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
The Chesterfield County School Board has created a new Environmental Stewardship Advisory Committee (ESAC) to assist in reviewing, evaluating, and making recommendations with regard to current and best practice efforts to sustain and enhance the quality of life as directly tied to school operations and facilities, as well as general public awareness.

The Environmental Stewardship Advisory Committee will consist of 10 members to be appointed by the School Board, with two members from each of the five magisterial districts. All seats currently are open for application.

To learn more or to apply, visit bit.ly/EnvironmentalStewardshipAdvisoryCommittee

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

The Chesterfield Food Bank is on the move! Their mission is to have a food distribution location within easy access no matter where you live in Chesterfield. Before schools closed, Robious Elementary School kicked off 50 books for 50 years to celebrate the school's 50th birthday and Read Across America Week. When schools closed, they found a way to continue the celebration virtually and recently wrapped up the extended competition. The students have voted, and the winner is...

post_text:
Annually, every Chesterfield County school selects a Teacher of the Year.

Chesterfield County Public Schools selects from those honorees an Elementary School Teacher of the Year, a Middle School Teacher of the Year and a High School Teacher of the Year, and ultimately chooses the countywide Teacher of the Year from those three honorees.

Congrats to our Teachers of the Year! #oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
The FACE FWD Film Series continues with an upcoming streaming event, Angst a documentary, which will be available to stream from May 26 - May 31, 2020.

Angst is an IndieFlix Original documentary designed to raise awareness around anxiety. The film includes interviews with kids, teens, educators, experts, parents, and a very special interview with Michael Phelps.

CCPS families can view the film and a resource-filled webinar led by Dr. Connie Honsinger, NBCT Intervention & Training Specialist for Trauma Informed Care for CCPS.

Virtual seats are limited. Please register here to save your spot: bit.ly/FACE-film

post_text:
Chesterfield County school leaders and School Board members caravanned across the Richmond region today to honor three Chesterfield County educators singled out for being the best of the best. These teachers were surprised at their homes with blaring car horns, balloons, flowers and large yard signs acknowledging their Teacher of the Year status!

Congrats to our 2021 Teachers of the Year!

- High school and Chesterfield County Public Schools’ 2021 Teacher of the Year: Chef Sarah Jurewicz, who teaches Culinary Arts I and II at the Career and Technical Center @ Courthouse
- Middle school: Katie Moore, a sixth-grade social studies teacher at Falling Creek Middle
- Elementary school: Heather Russell, a STEAM teacher at Ecoff Elementary

To see a complete list of #oneCCPS Teachers of the Year by school, or to read more about our top three teacher, please click the link below.
bit.ly/CCPS-2021-TeachersOfTheYear
#CCPSstrong

post_text: We have such kind, thoughtful students, like Jenae, who are using their talents to make others smile in a time when it's needed most. Thank you, Jenae, for going above and beyond for the letters of love campaign and for bringing joy to the residents at Lucy Corr! #oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #InThisTogetherCfield #KindnessMatters
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Virginia Government
May 12 at 4:01 PM ·

Meet Jenae. She heard about the Letters of Love campaign and decided to kick it up a notch by making paintings for seniors. Her mom will be delivering these paintings to Lucy Corr this week.

Thank you Jenae for sharing your talent! Your artwork will bring a smile to many residents and staff at Lucy Corr. We love seeing our youth going above and beyond to bring joy to the people in their community! #InThisTogetherCfield

post_text:
Team Chesterfield Class of 2020 and families,

Graduation is an annual rite of passage for high school seniors – an opportunity to celebrate 13 years’ worth of friendships, hard work and amazing academic accomplishments with family and staff members.

Within the next month, Chesterfield County Public Schools will offer two opportunities (one private, one public) to honor and celebrate the Class of 2020.

To read the full Class of 2020 graduation update, please visit: mychesterfieldschools.com

Chesterfield County Public Schools would shift to a pre-Labor Day start beginning with the 2021-22 school year, according to a draft calendar scheduled to be presented to the School Board during its May 12 work session.

The Chesterfield School Board is seeking input on the proposed 2021-22 school calendar. To see the proposed calendar, or to read this entire article, please visit: mychesterfieldschools.com

Comments about the proposed 2021-22 calendars can be sent to calendar@ccpsnet.net.

post_text:
Advisory committees established by the Chesterfield County School Board are one way that community members connect with their local schools. Advisory committee members are appointed from each of the county’s five magisterial districts and include parents, teachers, staff members, students and other community members interested in helping Chesterfield County Public Schools achieve its vision of creating a better tomorrow.

The Chesterfield School Board and Superintendent are currently seeking applicants for open advisory committee seats. To see the open committee seats, or to read this entire article, please visit: mychesterfieldschools.com

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

Right now, we are all facing challenges that can impact our mental health. Throughout the month, we'll have some tips on self care, support, reflection and connection, or for information right now, visit https://mhanational.org/mental-health-month.

post_text:
This morning, the Bellwood Elementary staff met down the street from their school to implement a top-secret plan. They surprised their #LunchHeroes with a teacher parade!

Staff drove by honking and playing the song "When You Rise Up." They gave their lunch heroes flowers, heartfelt gifts and LOTS of cards. The Bellwood Bulldogs created posters with special messages and wore super hero capes to celebrate their Food and Nutrition Services team members!

post_text:

No matter how you slice it, these individuals are an integral part of Team Chesterfield! Thank you for all you do! Help us celebrate our #LunchHeroes by leaving them a message in the comments!
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong #FeedingOurKids

post_text:
Team Chesterfield's Game Changers are:

- those who step up to meet the needs of our students;
- offer support and access to resources that assist their colleagues;
- provide an extra layer of support for families outside of the classroom; and
- who generally make a positive and sometimes life-changing difference in the lives of our students, families and their colleagues.

Please let us know who we should consider for this recognition and why by simply completing this short nomination form: bit.ly/2020GameChangers

post_text: Thank you, Communities In Schools of Chesterfield, for taking our community members on a virtual bus tour! We appreciate all you do to teach them more about the supports provided to #oneCCPS students and families in the midst of school closures. #CCPSstrong #ChesterfieldStrong
shared_text:
Communities In Schools of Chesterfield
April 27 at 10:30 AM ·

Because we are unable to go on our regularly scheduled bus tours, CIS of Chesterfield invites you to join us for a virtual tour! On this tour, you will learn more about the supports our team is continuing to provide CCPS students and families in the midst of school closures. Thank you for joining us!

post_text:
Approximately 2,500 additional Chromebooks are being distributed to students in Grades 2-4 this week, allowing the school division to further expand an Anytime, Anywhere Learning laptop take-home program that already is believed to be one of the largest in the country.

By next week, nearly 40,000 Chromebooks will be available to be used at home by students while school buildings are closed due to COVID-19.

To read this full update, click here: bit.ly/CCPS-ChromebookTakeHome
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

text:
Teacher Appreciation Week is next week! We are asking for your help telling our teachers just how much they mean to all of us.

Over the next week, please send us videos of your child sharing a special message to their teacher. We'd love to see our students get creative with chalk messages, silly props, handmade art, one-of-a-kind songs, emotion-filled poetry, or anything else your child wants to do to express themself.

For a chance to be featured in our teacher appreciation video, please submit your video by 11:59 p.m. on Friday, May 1, 2020. Submit videos here: bit.ly/CCPS-ThankATeacher

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

As we continue online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, students will be spending extra time in front of a screen. As our children mature and crave more privacy, it can be hard to have a window into their online world.

This Engage Chesterfield podcast shares research, explores trends, and gives you tips from Barbara Huth, the Education Program Manager for Common Sense Education.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

ENGAGECHESTERFIELD.BUZZSPROUT.COM

post_text:
Tiana, a senior at Chesterfield Career and Technical Center at Courthouse, was recently selected as the high school winner for the Virginia Lottery's Thank a Teacher art contest. The Lottery received several hundred entries earlier this year and selected one each from the elementary, middle and high school levels.

Tiana's winning design will be featured on thousands of note cards delivered to teachers as part of the fifth annual Thank a Teacher campaign. Congrats, Tiana! We're so proud of your accomplishment!

Want to see Tiana's reaction when she found out she was the winner? See it here: https://vimeo.com/405969627

Want to send a #oneCCPS teacher a thank you card that has one of the winning designs on it? Visit thankateacherva.com now through May 8 to send your digital note. (Each digital note will randomly showcase one of the winning designs.)

post_text: We already know that our Food Services Heroes are doing amazing things, and now people across the nation know it too! Our Team Chesterfield Food and Nutrition Services members were recently featured on Food Management's Facebook page and website for their innovative approach to serving our #oneCCPS families. Congrats for this well deserved recognition! #BeTheChange #ThankYou #CCPSstrong
shared_text:
Food Management
April 13 at 12:43 PM ·

Chesterfield County Public Schools Food & Nutrition Services is helping their students and their community by serving breakfast and lunch meals that are provided for seven days a week during this crisis. Chesterfield County Public Schools is a district of 65 schools where currently 33 schools are preparing meals that are being distributed by kiosks, and student transportation buses.

We’ve been so honored by the amazing work onsite operators are doing. So tell us what you’re doing to serve your community, customers and staff. If you have a story you'd like to share let us know in the comments below or send an email to Becky Schilling at Becky.Schilling@informa.com.

post_text:
In case you missed it...
Chesterfield County Public Schools will launch Call CCPS in an effort to continue to support Chesterfield County students and families with their needs related to academics, technology, and social and emotional questions. The new call center will also help connect families with community resources they may need during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Call CCPS will be open Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. until 1 p.m. through June 12. The call center officially opens on Monday, April 20.

Chesterfield County Public Schools families can call 804-639-8689 for support. Translation support will be available immediately in Spanish, or within a short period of time in other languages through the school division’s language line support program.

For the full update, visit bit.ly/CCPS-CallCenter

Call CCPS will be open Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. until 1 p.m. through June 12. The call center officially opens on Monday, April 20.

Chesterfield County Public Schools families can call 804-639-8689 for support. Translation support will be available immediately in Spanish, or within a short period of time in other languages through the school division’s language line support program.

For the full update, visit bit.ly/CCPS-CallCenter

post_text:
Team Chesterfield,

Throughout this week, we’ll be sharing video messages and words of encouragement from our School Board.

It’s likely fair to say that when they took office just four short months ago, a mid-March end of in-person instruction for the rest of the school year was not on their (or anyone’s) radar screen.

We appreciate their ongoing leadership, guidance and support during these trying times, as we work to adapt to provide students with learning experiences that will help them be prepared for success during the 2020-21 school year!

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong
text:
Team Chesterfield,

Throughout this week, we’ll be sharing video messages and words of encouragement from our School Board.

It’s likely fair to say that when they took office just four short months ago, a mid-March end of in-person instruction for the rest of the school year was not on their (or anyone’s) radar screen.

We appreciate their ongoing leadership, guidance and support during these trying times, as we work to adapt to provide students with learning experiences that will help them be prepared for success during the 2020-21 school year!

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

Want a few conversation starters? Check these out!

post_text:
Daily routines should be re-established. Many of us do better when we have schedules, and learning from home shouldn’t be different. Adults who work at home have shared they are more productive after their morning routine of getting dressed for work and not spending the day in their pajamas.

Not sure where to start in terms of schedule development? Khan Academy has created four sample schedules for preK-12 students grouped by grade level. See the schedules here: bit.ly/KhanSchedules

Haga clic aquí para ver los horarios en español: bit.ly/KhanSpanishSchedules

In case you missed it... Chesterfield County Public Schools continues to provide support for school division-issued Chromebooks:

• Every Tuesday at Thomas Dale and Matoaca high schools from 9 a.m. until noon
• Every Thursday at CTC@Hull and Robious Middle from 1-4 p.m.

A parent and/or student will need to provide their student ID number in order to adjust the school division’s inventory records. Support is limited to students in grades 5-12, who already are participating in the Chromebook take-home program.

Appropriate social distancing protocol will be followed to protect students and staff.

The CCPS Internet network is available to families while in school parking lots.

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families,

Meals service continues this coming week!

To meet the needs of students during COVID-19 school closures, Chesterfield County Public Schools continues provide meals for students for pick-up without charge and regardless of race, color, national origin, sex, age or disability and without discrimination. Meals will be provided on a first-come, first-served basis at the sites and times listed below.

Please note these important pieces of information related to the distribution of meals:
• Children do not have to be present to pick up meals. To pick up meals without a student present, please tell the staff member your student’s first and last names and age.
• On Mondays and Wednesdays, two lunches and two breakfasts will be provided for each child.
• On Fridays, three lunches and three breakfasts will be provided for each child.
• No meal service is available on Tuesdays or Thursdays.

See the attached documents for locations.

April 10 at 11:02 AM ·

We’re making it easier for you to provide comments about the revised Chesterfield County FY2021 budget from your own home.

Gather around your phone or computer, and join Deputy County Administrator Matt Harris for a Facebook Live session about revisions to the proposed FY2021 budget at 7 p.m. Monday, April 13 right here on Chesterfield’s main Facebook page.

Submit questions or comments about the revised budget any time using an online form available at blueprint.chesterfield.gov; or during the Facebook Live session on April 9 once the event is launched.

All revisions and proposals to the Chesterfield FY2021 budget can be found at blueprint.chesterfield.gov.

With many of you taking Virtual Spring Break trips this week, we wanted to remind you that Comcast Xfinity hotspots are open for public use during the COVID-19 health crisis.

Students without Internet access can select this option when using their Chromebooks. CCPS Internet filtering will still be active. There is no charge for using this service.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Is your child's school division-issued Chromebook not working correctly? No problem! We have support available over Spring Break:

-Every Tuesday at Thomas Dale and Matoaca high schools from 9 a.m. until noon.
-Every Thursday at CTC@Hull and Robious Middle from 1-4 p.m.

A parent and/or student will need to provide their student ID number in order to adjust the school division’s inventory records. Support is limited to students in grades 5-12, who already are participating in the Chromebook take-home program.

Appropriate social distancing protocol will be followed to protect students and staff.

For clarification purposes: While the CCPS Internet network is available to families while in the parking lot, the school division is not giving out free hotspot devices at these repair stations.

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
In case you missed it...
Meals service will continue during Spring Break!

To meet the needs of students during COVID-19 school closures, Chesterfield County Public Schools continues provide meals for students for pick-up without charge and regardless of race, color, national origin, sex, age or disability and without discrimination. Meals will be provided on a first-come, first-served basis at the sites and times listed below.

Please note these important pieces of information related to the distribution of meals:

-Children do not have to be present to pick up meals. To pick up meals without a student present, please tell the staff member your student’s first and last names and age.
-On Mondays and Wednesdays, two lunches and two breakfasts will be provided for each child.
-On Fridays, three lunches and three breakfasts will be provided for each child.
-No meal service is available on Tuesdays or Thursdays.

See the attached documents for locations.
#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families,

Our school buildings may be closed and in-person teaching may have been stopped, but student learning opportunities continue.

We appreciate our families’ patience as we adapt to this temporary new norm and continue to receive updated guidance from the state. The Virginia Department of Education has encouraged local school divisions to identify content that had not been taught prior to school closure and develop a plan to incorporate missing content into learning opportunities for all students.

To read the full update, visit: https://mychesterfieldschools.com/moving-forward-with-instruction

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families,

As we receive new guidance daily from the state and federal levels, Chesterfield County Public Schools continues to adjust plans for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. Please keep in mind that while school buildings are closed for in-person instruction, learning continues. Our role now is to continue to prepare students for success in the 2020-21 academic year to the best of our ability.

Today’s communication includes information about grading. We apologize in advance for the length of this message, but want to be as clear as possible about our work and expectations related to it.

Read the full grades and grading update here: http://mychesterfieldschools.com/grading-overview/

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

shared_text:
Communities In Schools of Chesterfield
March 27 at 10:30 AM ·

UPDATE - LOCATION CHANGE! The supply drive drop-off location has moved to the Chesterfield Food Bank (12211 Iron Bridge Road, Chester, VA)! Same supplies needed - Help us continue to support our students and families by collecting NEW and sanitized items from the list below!
School Supplies: Pencils, Pencil Sharpeners, Notebooks (not spiral), Children's Scissors
Enrichment Activities: Kids Books (including Spanish), Puzzles, Arts & Crafts, Games, Jump Ropes
Hygiene Items: Hand Sanitizer, Soap, Shampoo (for all hair types), Toothbrushes, Toothpaste, Feminine Hygiene Products
Household Items: Spray Cleaner, Toilet Paper, Paper Towels, Dish Soap, Laundry Detergent

post_text: We're so appreciative of the information and resources that Chesterfield County Prevention Services is sharing with our #oneCCPS families and community. #CCPSstrong
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Prevention Services
March 26 at 8:00 AM ·

Chesterfield County realizes the coronavirus, or Covid-19, has impacted Chesterfield residents’ work, home, educational, recreational and social lives. Utilizing practical ways to cope and relax, maintaining social connections and doing things to positively impact others are all ways to promote positive mental health through this time of stress, change and loss. To this end, Chesterfield County is launching our Calm, Connected, Caring Chesterfield campaign which will provide daily tips on this Facebook page on topics related to practical ways to cope and relax, maintain important social connections and do things to positively impact others. We welcome your ideas on these topics as well.
text:
We're so appreciative of the information and resources that Chesterfield County Prevention Services is sharing with our #oneCCPS families and community. #CCPSstrong

To this end, Chesterfield County is launching our Calm, Connected, Caring Chesterfield campaign which will provide daily tips on this Facebook page on topics related to practical ways to cope and relax, maintain important social connections and do things to positively impact others. We welcome your ideas on these topics as well.

post_text:
Teachers across the county are finding creative ways to stay engaged with their students. This week, teachers from C.C. Wells and J.B. Watkins elementary schools drove around the neighborhoods in which their students live to help lift their spirits. Keep an eye out for a #oneCCPS Teacher Parade near you soon!

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families and staff:

Week 1 of school closures is in the books, and we’re off to Week 2.

Teachers are preparing to release a second round of instructional activities that your child can work on while at home this week. If you have not received this update already, look for communication from your child’s teacher on Monday.

If you cannot access the materials online, these instructional materials will be available for pickup at your child’s school on Tuesday from 8 a.m.-1 p.m.

We appreciate your support of our students as we seek to keep them engaged in instructional activities and wellness-related opportunities through the closings that have been extended until at least April 14. Please be sure to visit https://sites.google.com/ccpsnet.net/ccps-parent-resources/home for additional instructional resources that supplement what is already being provided by our fantastic teachers.

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

post_text:
Day 6 without students …

Hope it’s not too early in the process, but we figured everyone needed a quick laugh today.

As we’ve all worked to begin to adapt to the new norm, we’ve been watching some of the memes and posts that have popped up this week. Thought we’d share a few here. Please feel free to add your favorite in the comments section.

Thank you families for your ability to react and adapt to the curveball life has thrown at us, and for working with us to continue to provide learning opportunities, recreational opportunities, etc. for our students. Thank you to our teachers and other staff who are reaching out to families, providing learning resources and adjusting to a new service model.

That said, the new norm stinks. We want our students and staff back!

#oneCCPS #CCPSstrong

shared_text:
Chesterfield County Public Library
March 16 at 6:47 PM ·

All CCPL buildings will be closed to customers through Saturday, March 21. CCPL continues to follow guidelines put forward by state and health officials regarding the Covid-19 virus.
Staff will be able to offer assistance over the phone between 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Please call 804-751-CCPL to speak to staff.
Fines related to the closure will be waived. Due dates will be extended. Holds currently on the holds shelf will be made available after buildings reopen.
Please do not return any materials (or drop off any donations) until further notice.
And remember, we are available 24/7 at library.chesterfield.gov. Check out our Stream and Download page for access to online magazines, tv shows, movies, books and music.

post_text:
UPDATED WITH ADDITION/CLARIFICATION:

Chesterfield County Public Schools will provide free meals to students while the school division is closed during the next two weeks due to COVID-19.

Meals are for children ages 18 and younger, and will be available for pickup at a Food Services kiosk located outside of the school. The attached chart provides school and community locations at which food is available and the hours of service. (Ettrick ES has been added as a distribution site. Reams ES pickup will occur at the Reams mobile village behind the Davis ES campus.)

This program provides lunch for that particular day (Monday-Friday) and breakfast for the next morning. Meals will be provided on a first-come, first-served basis. Children must be present.
#oneCCPS

For more information, please visit our website: https://mychesterfieldschools.com/coronavirus-information/

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families,

These are unprecedented times. Unprecedented times call for unprecedented measures.

With the Governor’s declared state of emergency due to COVID-19 and today’s regional guidance that there are no large gatherings of more than 250 people at one place at one time, we are taking the unprecedented step of closing schools due to public health concerns.

Effective Saturday, March 14, through at least Friday, March 27, Chesterfield County Public Schools will be closed.

To read this entire #oneCCPS update, please visit: https://mychesterfieldschools.com/coronavirus-information/

post_text:
Thank you for your continued support and patience during this difficult time! The decisions we make are made with the best interests of our students, staff, schools and community in mind.

The Superintendent’s leadership team will meet again Friday to review the latest conditions and guidance regarding COVID-19. As we do during inclement weather season, we strongly encourage parents to have emergency childcare plans prearranged in the event they are needed in the coming days or weeks.

A couple of important updates to share:

* Earlier today we noted that school activities scheduled for Friday afternoon and evening would be held as scheduled. That guidance has changed. Other than the staff workday, no school or school division events involving students will be held on Friday. This includes the previously scheduled secondary band assessment.

* Students who are taking courses through CCPSOnline will proceed as normal in the event that there is a need for a long-term closure of schools.

Thank you again for your continued support of Chesterfield County Public Schools!

post_text:
Team Chesterfield families,

COVID-19 has created a rapidly evolving environment where changes are being made quickly in the interest of public health. Just within the last 24 hours, the World Health Organization has declared an international pandemic; travel from parts of the world to the U.S. has been extremely restricted; Virginia colleges and universities have adjusted student schedules; and states across the country are curtailing events with large numbers of people attending.

While many are focused on individual positive test results, we are just as concerned about potential exposure, the subsequent 14 days of self-quarantine that are recommended by the Centers for Disease Control, and the instructional time potentially lost in such a case. Our schools need time to proactively prepare lessons should it become necessary to close for an extended period of time.

As a result, Chesterfield County Public Schools will be closed to students on Friday, March 13. #oneCCPS (To read the full article, click the attached link.)

MYCHESTERFIELDSCHOOLS.COM

post_text:
Hall of Fame Spotlight: Dr. Jane Baskerville

During her 30-plus years in education, Dr. Baskerville served as a world language instructor, a foreign language department chair, an instructional specialist for foreign languages and later the specialist for English as a Second Language (ESL). After retirement, Dr. Baskerville earned her Ph. D. in Educational Leadership and Policy Studies and went on to become a consultant in the Office of School Improvement at the Virginia Department of Education.

If you'd like to show your support of Dr. Jane Baskerville's #oneCCPS career, you can purchase tickets to attend the 2020 Hall of Fame Gala here: bit.ly/CCPSHOF

This is a friendly reminder that there is not a three-hour early release this Friday, March 13. Students will attend school the entire day.

The early release originally scheduled was eliminated when March 3 became a #oneCCPS student holiday due to the Super Tuesday presidential primary. (Friday, March 20 is a full day of instruction for students attending a year-round elementary school, Bellwood and Falling Creek, instead of a three-hour early release for a teacher workday.)

The 2019-20 and 2020-21 calendars are available for review here: https://mychesterfieldschools.com/about/calendars/.

post_text:
Last spring, the RoboHawks Team 346 at L.C. Bird High School placed 4th in the world at the 2019 FIRST Robotics Competition championship out of 6,000 active teams from around the globe.

At the present time it takes a minimum of $26,000 each year to fund the build sessions and the registration fee for the competitions. On March 11 from 6- 8 p.m., they will host a silent auction fundraiser with all types of goodies and a not so silent auction for the right to name this year’s robot.

Auction items are online for your review at: https://www.robohawks346boosters.com/. Online bidding will stop on March 10 at 6 p.m. to allow time to process bids before the event Wednesday.

This event is open to everyone… the more the merrier!
#oneCCPS

post_text:
Hall of Fame Spotlight: Mr. Jamie Accashian

Throughout his career, Mr. Accashian was an innovative teacher, coach and administrator known for motivating at-risk students and helping them believe in themselves. As an administrator at Meadowbrook High, he helped create the Phoenix program to combat a higher than desired student dropout rate. From there, he became involved with Communities In Schools of Chesterfield and helped establish the Burger King Academy, an alternative program that helped at-risk students graduate. Burger King Academy went on to become Community High, where Mr. Accashian served as principal, continuing to champion the needs associated with alternative education.

If you'd like to show your support of Mr. Jamie Accashian's #oneCCPS career, you can purchase tickets to attend the 2020 Hall of Fame Gala here: bit.ly/CCPSHOF

post_text:
Earlier this week, the superintendent's leadership team met with principals to discuss monitoring and planning in the event COVID-19 makes its way to Virginia and Chesterfield County.

Cleaning of facilities, monitoring student and staff attendance, providing continuity in instruction and the delivery of food to students in need were points of that discussion. Our custodial teams focused on common touchpoints Tuesday during the student holiday, and our instructional team is working on options to support the continuity of operations as needed.

Our goal is to have a solid plan so that we are prepared and ready in the event we need to take action.
shared_text:
Chesterfield County Virginia Government
March 6 at 12:26 PM ·

Yesterday, regional partners from Chesterfield, Goochland County, VA, Hanover County, VA, Henrico County Government and City of Richmond, VA Government along with the Central Virginia Healthcare Coalition came together to activate the Central Virginia All-Hazards Incident Management Team to help guide the region's preparations for, and response to, a potential local occurrence of COVID-19.

As a region, we are committed to working with our state and local partners to safeguard our residents and make sure we share the most current information available. As of this writing, Virginia has zero confirmed cases of COVID-19. The immediate health risk to Virginians is considered to be low at the current time.

Read the region's full response: https://www.chesterfield.gov/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=1243

Chesterfield County Fire and EMS Chesterfield County Police Chesterfield County Sheriff’s Office Virginia Department of Health Richmond City Health District Chesterfield County Public Schools

Our goal is to have a solid plan so that we are prepared and ready in the event we need to take action.

Do you have a child who will be 4 years old by Sept. 30, 2020? Did you know that #oneCCPS offers prekindergarten at several elementary schools to provide school readiness skills to eligible children with the greatest need?

If you live in the attendance zone for either Bellwood or Falling Creek elementary schools, prekindergarten applications will be taken at Meadowdale Library on Thursday, Feb. 27 and Friday, Feb. 28. A limited number of prekindergarten spots are available and applying does not guarantee acceptance.

A list of schools that have a preK program, application event dates/ locations, a list of what you need to bring to application events, and the application forms can all be found here: bit.ly/CCPS-PreK

This is a FACE FWD film event you won't want to miss! Finding Kind is an emotionally intense but ultimately uplifting documentary about bullying among young girls. Best friends, Lauren and Molly, travel the country with a call to kindness. They speak to girls about their own experiences of being bullied and offer a road map out of despair.

For more information about this film or to register for this free event, visit bit.ly/FACEFWDFILM.

Teachers, did you know that you can get recertification points for attending this event? Simply register on Eventbrite to save your spot and register on Impact U to get your points. #oneCCPS

post_text:
In February, Chesterfield County Public Schools will join school divisions across Virginia in thanking School Board members for voluntarily tackling the enormous job of governing our local schools.

Board members contribute hundreds of hours each year leading their divisions. Whether it is crafting policies, hiring administrators, listening to staff and student concerns or recognizing outstanding programs, Board members always keep their eyes on the goal of student achievement.

Thank you, Kathryn Haines, for serving as our Midlothian District School Board Representative!
#oneCCPS

post_text:
Students in Ms. Cammer's class at Thomas Dale High School worked with Librarian, Ms. Knott, in the Makerspace to create Valentines earlier this week. Before they began, they talked about Valentine's Day being about love, friendship and kindness.

Ms. Knott precut the pieces for students to glue together, then she demonstrated the process while they followed along. Their teachers helped them sign their names to their cards when they were finished.

Students will give their card to someone they care about. #KindnessMatters #ChooseToInclude #oneCCPS

post_text:
Don't miss out! This free film event will discuss how boys are directed to grow up to be "men" -- and what it really means to be a man in today's society.

Teachers, did you know that you can get recertification points for attending this event? Simply register on Eventbrite (bit.ly/FACEFWDFILM) to save your spot and register on Impact U to get your points.#oneCCPS
shared_text:
CCPS Office of Family and Community Engagement
February 11 at 4:17 PM ·

Coming up next in the FACE FWD film series, Tuesday, February 18, 2020- The Mask You Live In. A documentary. From the filmmakers:

The Mask You Live In follows boys and young men as they struggle to stay true to themselves while negotiating America’s narrow definition of masculinity.

Pressured by the media, their peer group, and even the adults in their lives, our protagonists confront messages encouraging them to disconnect from their emotions, devalue authentic friendships, objectify and degrade women, and resolve conflicts through violence. These gender stereotypes interconnect with race, class, and circumstance, creating a maze of identity issues boys and young men must navigate to become “real” men.

Experts in neuroscience, psychology, sociology, sports, education, and media also weigh in, offering empirical evidence of the “boy crisis” and tactics to combat it.

The Mask You Live In ultimately illustrates how we, as a society, can raise a healthier generation of boys and young men."

Free for CCPS Parents and Educators. Please register for tickets at http://bit.ly/FACEFWDFILM

We know we just started the second semester; however, we are already looking ahead at welcoming the Class of 2033!

If you will be sending a child to kindergarten during the 2020-21 school year, now is the time to start thinking about kindergarten registration.

We have an opportunity to save you some time on April 16, which is Kindergarten Registration Day at every elementary school in Chesterfield County.

Visit bit.ly/CCPS-K-registration2020 and preregister for kindergarten today! Doing so should cut your wait time in half on Kindergarten Registration Day.

Please remember to share this message with any family you know who has a rising #oneCCPS kindergarten child!

post_text:
This year, Woolridge Elementary School combined their traditional STEAM night with their Science Fair and classroom activities to create their first ever STEAM week! Throughout the week, #oneCCPS teachers incorporated STEAM activities into their lesson plans, and each class had the opportunity to design and engineer 30 paper snowman for a school-wide competition to celebrate their school's 30th anniversary.

The night of the event, there were STEAM activities for families, math games in the gym, a Robotics team came and demonstrated their robot, students presented their Science Fair or Engineering projects, and STEAMmania teams competed in challenges.

The middle school years can be a challenging time for many families. Transitioning from elementary to middle and middle to high school can be daunting. The school division’s Office of Family and Community Engagement is hosting a transition fair that will have strategies and resources for #oneCCPS families navigating these years of dramatic change.

This free event will be on Thursday, Feb. 20 from 6-8:30 p.m. at the Career and Technical Center @ Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road.

To register, please use the following link to Eventbrite: bit.ly/ccpsmiddleages2020

post_text:
The R.E.B. Awards provide opportunities for area public school teachers to continue their own love of learning as they pursue adventures of a lifetime.

Through a nomination process, approximately 15 outstanding teachers are selected each year to receive grants up to $12,000 to support professional development activities. Award recipients have earned graduate degrees, climbed mountains, traced their ancestors and met peers from around the world - all to reignite their own passion for learning and to pass it on to their students.

To begin the online nomination process, visit www.cfrichmond.org/REB.

Nomination Deadline is Feb. 24 by 5 p.m.
