post_text:
UPDATE:

Power has been restored at Manchester High School.
text:
UPDATE:

Power has been restored at Manchester High School.

post_text:
EDIT: Power has now been restored at Carver Middle.

Team Chesterfield families,

Power has come back on at many locations.

These schools are still without power: Manchester High, Carver Middle, and Bellwood Elementary.

Our Food Services team has prepared lunches for all sites without power, and students at those schools are now in areas with natural lighting.

Again, all of our students are now indoors and safe. No student are outdoors or in trailers. This is likely to be the case for the rest the afternoon.

We continue to monitor weather conditions and the forecast. Schools will continue to operate on their normal schedule. No change has been decided for afterschool activities.

Thank you for trusting us with your students!

post_text:
Familias del Equipo Chesterfield,

Debido a las fuertes ráfagas de viento, ahora tenemos varias escuelas que están funcionando sin electricidad esta mañana. Estamos compilando una lista completa y actualizaremos a los padres lo antes posible.

En este momento, no estamos considerando una salida temprana. Nuestros estudiantes están a salvo.

Todos los estudiantes en los remolques están siendo trasladados al interior del edificio principal. Las escuelas sin electricidad están trasladando a los estudiantes a áreas con luz natural. Nuestro equipo de Servicios de Alimentos está trabajando diligentemente para hacer planes para el almuerzo.

Actualizaremos tan pronto como tengamos información adicional.

post_text:
There are 112 new positions included in the Superintendent's proposed budget to support student enrollment growth. These positions include teachers, support staff and administrators.

This is the first year in several decades that the school division has included funding for support staff and administrators within its student enrollment growth calculation.

An expected 1,200 new students next year is the equivalent of a new middle school, meaning we need the appropriate level of human resources to serve these new-to-Chesterfield learners.

Come join the conversation at tonight's community meeting! All are welcome! #oneCCPS #SpeakUp4CCPS

post_text:
The proposed operating budget for the 2020-21 school year provides funds for staffing levels that meet state law, state guidelines, community expectations and provide equity in services across the division.

All funding proposed begins to right-size public education in Chesterfield County to meet the demands of a continually increasing student enrollment, something that has not necessarily been accomplished during the past decade.

Each community meeting will include a budget presentation and question-and-answer period. There is no requirement to sign up in advance to attend or speak. Come join the discussion at tonight's community meeting! #oneCCPS #SpeakUp4CCPS

post_text:
The Superintendent's proposed budget focus is simple: We need to meet the needs of our students through appropriate staffing levels; we need to provide additional staffing to support an increasing student enrollment; we need to meet the needs of our teachers and staff by offering competitive compensation; and we need to meet the needs associated with our daily operations by funding actual costs.

Join the discussion at tonight's community meeting! #oneCCPS #SpeakUp4CCPS

post_text:
It's time we stop asking parents and teachers to fund school-based instructional materials, student activities and field trips!

The Superintendent’s budget proposal recommends that school-based instructional accounts be right-sized from the current base amount of $51-57 per pupil and adjusted for cumulative inflation over 20 years to a new base allocation of $89 per pupil. #oneCCPS #SpeakUp4CCPS

Want to learn more?

Here is the Differentiated School Funds presentation from yesterday's School Board Budget Work Session: bit.ly/DifferentiatedSchoolFunds

This document shows what each school would get: bit.ly/FundingCCPSEquity

Do you know a student artist? The Virginia Lottery’s annual Thank a Teacher Art Contest is still accepting submissions online until Jan. 31. Winners will be selected from three levels: elementary school, middle school and high school.

In addition to having their original artwork featured on thousands of 2020 thank-you notes distributed across the Commonwealth, winners will each receive $2,000 for their school’s art department and a $150 gift card.

For more information about the Thank a Teacher Art Contest eligibility requirements, design criteria, prize structure and submission guidelines, visit www.ThankaTeacherVA.com.

post_text:
Did you know that in addition to a proposed pay increase for teachers, bus drivers, and instructional and support staff, the Superintendent’s budget proposal recommends that school-based instructional accounts be right-sized too?

In the Superintendent's budget proposal, the per-student allocation given to schools to support spending for instructional supplies and academic supports would increase for the first time in more than 20 years!

Come join the budget discussion! This evening's community meeting will include a budget presentation and a question-and-answer period. All are welcome! #oneCCPS #SpeakUp4CCPS

post_text:
This past Saturday, Hening Elementary's STEAM resource teacher, Dawn Estrada, hosted a STEAM in our Schools workshop for teachers at Barnes and Noble. Teachers from #oneCCPS elementary and middle schools, plus a private school here in Chesterfield, gave up their Saturday to attend the event.

Teachers shared what they do to combine literature with their STEAM units. Teachers had the chance to look at projects students worked on at both Hening Elementary and Falling Creek Middle School. Then they had the opportunity to make their own project and learn how to use various robots and technology.

We'd like to send a big shout out to our community partner, Jenny Friedmann, from the Chesterfield Towne Center Barnes and Noble for hosting the workshop and supporting local teachers!
text:
This past Saturday, Hening Elementary's STEAM resource teacher, Dawn Estrada, hosted a STEAM in our Schools workshop for teachers at Barnes and Noble. Teachers from #oneCCPS elementary and middle schools, plus a private school here in Chesterfield, gave up their Saturday to attend the event.

Teachers shared what they do to combine literature with their STEAM units. Teachers had the chance to look at projects students worked on at both Hening Elementary and Falling Creek Middle School. Then they had the opportunity to make their own project and learn how to use various robots and technology.

We'd like to send a big shout out to our community partner, Jenny Friedmann, from the Chesterfield Towne Center Barnes and Noble for hosting the workshop and supporting local teachers!

post_text:
The #oneCCPS Fiscal Year 2021 budget proposal calls for $36.5 million in new funds to be invested in salaries for all employees. In addition to addressing the teacher salary compression, the funding request provides at least a 2 percent increase for instructional and support staff. Bus drivers also would receive their second $0.75 raise in six months, putting them closer to the $17 per hour mark often seen in the private sector.

This evening's community meeting will include a budget presentation and a question-and-answer period. We invite you to join in the discussion; all are welcome!

The #oneCCPS Fiscal Year 2021 budget proposal calls for $36.5 million in new funds to be invested in salaries for all employees. In addition to addressing the teacher salary compression, the funding request provides at least a 2 percent increase for instructional and support staff. Bus drivers also would receive their second $0.75 raise in six months, putting them closer to the $17 per hour mark often seen in the private sector.

This evening's community meeting will include a budget presentation and a question-and-answer period. We invite you to join in the discussion; all are welcome!

post_text:
The Superintendent’s budget proposal calls for an additional $99.9 million to be invested in Chesterfield County schools. It includes:
- resources to serve students projected to enroll in our schools next year
- historic levels of support for teachers
- required staffing levels to meet laws guidelines and expectations
- additional funds necessary to support a diverse learning community
- covering the actual costs of day-to-day operations

Not sure how budget planning for a school system works? This video is here to help! We hope that you’ll join our efforts to help create a better tomorrow -- for our students and our community. #oneCCPS

Team Chesterfield,

Below are the two draft calendars for the 2020-21 school year currently before the School Board for consideration. (The year-round school calendar would apply to Bellwood and Falling Creek elementary schools.)

Based on feedback from September 2019, both 2020-21 calendar proposals include a staggered start for kindergarten, sixth-grade students and high school students.

The Board is scheduled to vote on the calendars during is Feb. 11 meeting.

Feel free to share your comments via calendar@ccpsnet.net.

post_text:
Monacan High School students in Ms. Carson's art class are donating their time and talents for a great cause! Their artwork will not only be on display along with professional artists, but it will also be auctioned off with the proceeds going to the Richmond Animal League (RAL). We are so proud of these #oneCCPS students for their hard work and dedication to helping animals!

For those who are interested in viewing their art, it will be on display at the Crossroads Art Center on Feb. 2 from 12- 3:45 p.m.

If you are interested in supporting our students and their cause, the auction will be at the RAL's Sugar and Spice Gala on Feb. 22 at Willow Oaks Country Club.

post_text:
If you really want your #oneCCPS students to be reading over winter break, you promise them you'll do a Polar Plunge when they get back! Today, students at JG Hening Elementary who committed to reading over the holiday break cheered on their admin team as they took turns sliding into icy water!

Mr. Fillman, Mrs. Thomas, Ms. Booker and Mr. Cartwright were thrilled to see how many students were there to count down their plunge into the frigid water on this chilly day!

Special thanks goes out to community partner, Moon Rock Inflatables LLC, for donating their time and equipment to make this event possible. We appreciate your kindness and generosity!

YOUTUBE.COM
Polar Plunge for Reading!

post_text:
Whether it’s teachers, administrators, support staff or community volunteers, our nationally recognized school division has been supported by individuals who have given their time and talents to impact our students’ education in a meaningful way.

Nominees for our #oneCCPS Hall of Fame should be memorable educators and volunteers who have made a significant difference in our schools.

To nominate someone who has made a lasting impact on our students, schools and community, please fill out this form : http://bit.ly/CCPS-2020-Hall-of-Fame

Nominations are due by Jan. 10, 2020.
text:
Whether it’s teachers, administrators, support staff or community volunteers, our nationally recognized school division has been supported by individuals who have given their time and talents to impact our students’ education in a meaningful way.

Nominees for our #oneCCPS Hall of Fame should be memorable educators and volunteers who have made a significant difference in our schools.

To nominate someone who has made a lasting impact on our students, schools and community, please fill out this form : http://bit.ly/CCPS-2020-Hall-of-Fame

Nominations are due by Jan. 10, 2020.

post_text:
Chesterfield County Council of PTAs and the Office of Family and Community Engagement invite you to join us and our superintendent, Dr. Merv Daugherty, as he talks about the pressing issues facing CCPS, including the budget process and ways we can support and advocate for public education and our students.

Dr. Daugherty will speak on Monday, January 13, from 6:30-7:30 p.m. at the Career & Technical Center at 13900 Hull Street Road, Midlothian VA 23112.

We hope that you will join us!

To relieve overcrowding at Winterpock Elementary, the School Board and Board of Supervisors have approved construction plans for a new #oneCCPS elementary school that soon will be built in the Magnolia Green subdivision.

The school division will host a community meeting in the cafeteria at Winterpock Elementary on Jan. 15 at 6:30 p.m. to discuss construction plans. For more information, please visit mychesterfieldschools.com

post_text:
Monacan students in Ms Thompson and Mrs. Fera's Life Skills and Transition to Employment classes were inspired by their positive start to the school year, and they wanted to keep the momentum going. They decided to focus their efforts on continuing to spread encouraging messages and kindness through their school based business.

These #oneCCPS students recently created ornaments, magnets and gift tags with thoughtful and uplifting messages and sold them during lunches in order to help them improve their social and employment skills. The entire school was extremely supportive of their efforts! #KindnessMatters #ChooseToInclude #ThankYou

post_text:
#oneCCPS students in the Cisco Networking Academy at CTC Courthouse shared in the spirit of the giving season by helping local families in need. Students spent time over Thanksgiving break refurbishing laptop computers that were then given to deserving families in our Chesterfield community.

At the annual VA STAR Bridging the Tech Gap event, Cisco Networking Academy students served up dinner, gave away touchscreen laptops, and provided one on one instruction to families on IT security and proper use of the technology, at no cost to the families.

We're so proud of these students for recognizing a need and giving of their time and talents so selflessly. #KindnessMatters #ThankYou

Reminder: This evening, the Office of Family and Community Engagement will be hosting an event that will help #oneCCPS students understand their PSAT scores by teaching participants:

*Why the PSAT is important
*How to interpret the PSAT Score Sheet
*How to prepare for the SAT
*Resources to assist in college readiness and planning
*College Board scholarship opportunities

The event will be held from 6:30-7:30 p.m. at the Career and Technical Center @ Hull, located at 13900 Hull Street Road. If you wish to attend, please register at: ccpspsat.eventbrite.com.

post_text:
Congrats to Katherine Krievs, a junior at Midlothian High School, who is a finalist for the Children’s Museum of Richmond's 2020 Snow Queen Scholarship!

The college scholarship is offered each year to a high school junior who best exemplifies good character. The Snow Queen serves as a community role model by demonstrating internal beauty, strong character and a commitment to inspiring creativity and individuality in all children.

Katherine is the only contestant representing Chesterfield County Public Schools. She is competing against two other young ladies, and every vote counts. We'd love to spread the word and earn her some votes!

Vote here: bit.ly/CCPS-SnowQueen

As part of Chesterfield County Public Schools’ free PSAT For All initiative, all students in grades 8-11 took the PSAT during school in October. Scores will be released and delivered electronically to #oneCCPS students today, via their College Board account.

Not sure how to interpret the scores? Join us on Tues., Dec. 17 from 6:30- 7:30 p.m. for tips and helpful resources.

post_text: Tammie Peterson-Wilford impacts our #oneCCPS students every single day! She may not be in a classroom, but when you’re walking through the halls at Carver College and Career Academy, you will quickly see that she has built positive relationships with almost every student. Every morning, she’s greeting students by name with a smile and a word of encouragement. She wants them to feel safe, supported, and have a reason to come to school. #ThankYou #SomeoneYouShouldKnow

post_text: Today might be #GivingTuesday, but #oneCCPS students at Harrowgate Elementary School decided they wanted to give back to their community before Thanksgiving break. post_text:
Wells Elementary families received the following message via phone and email:
“Hello Wells Families: I know it’s unusual for you to hear from me at this time of day, but I am contacting families to let you know that Wells Elementary will need to close at 11:15 am. Buses are being routed to school now and students will be taken home. We will be offering lunch to all students. If your child does not ride the bus, please make arrangements to come to school to pick up your child. Over the break, the school division's hired cleaning vendor redid the floors in our school; however, the smell this morning is still quite noticeable. We understand that this change in our dismissal time is an incredible inconvenience. I will contact families later this afternoon or early this evening with an update about tomorrow’s schedule. We appreciate your patience and understanding as we work to adapt to the situation that have been presented.”

Robious Elementary School PTA is feeling thankful.
November 22, 2019 at 7:33 PM ·

Today, Robious Elementary Kindergarten and 3rd Grade buddy CREWS celebrated their first Friendsgiving while learning there is more than one story of Thanksgiving. Our special guest, Chickahominy Tribe member Dawn Tupponce, spoke to students about Native American traditions. Then everyone enjoyed a shared feast with food donations from class parents. 💛💙💛💙 #Friendsgiving #RES #RobiousWay #oneCCPS #BuddyCrews

Yesterday, the Chesterfield Food Bank picked up six large bins containing an assortment of food items from Winterpock Elementary! Their PTA, along with a school service group, the K-Kids, held a food drive over the past few weeks. Each week, Winterpock families were asked to donate specific items to help the Chesterfield Food Bank meet their donation goal of 60,000 lbs of food for the month of November.

Thank you Winterpock students, families, and staff for helping the Chesterfield Food Bank serve citizens throughout our Chesterfield community. We appreciate your kindness and willingness to help others! #oneCCPS #KindnessMatters

post_text: It's School Psychology Awareness Week! This year's theme is "Find Your Focus" 🔍 CCPS school psychologists find their focus by improving school climate, advocating for students, & removing barriers to school success. #SPAW2019 #oneCCPS #SchoolPsychsOneCCPS

post_text:
November 11-15, 2019 is School Psychology Awareness Week! School psychologists are vital members of our student support teams who apply expertise in mental health, learning, and behavior to help children and youth succeed academically, socially, behaviorally, and emotionally.

This year’s theme for School Psychology Awareness Week is “Find Your Focus.” Finding one’s focus can mean a variety of things from paying attention, to being able to see an idea more clearly, to identifying an area of interest, or being persistent or determined in one’s effort.
text:
November 11-15, 2019 is School Psychology Awareness Week! School psychologists are vital members of our student support teams who apply expertise in mental health, learning, and behavior to help children and youth succeed academically, socially, behaviorally, and emotionally.

This year’s theme for School Psychology Awareness Week is “Find Your Focus.” Finding one’s focus can mean a variety of things from paying attention, to being able to see an idea more clearly, to identifying an area of interest, or being persistent or determined in one’s effort.

Help #oneCCPS seniors fund their new hotspot devices and bridge the digital divide at James River High School. Sophie and Kate will host a Digital Divide Auction Night in the James River High School Library TONIGHT (Nov. 7) from 6-8 p.m.

At this event, attendees will be given the opportunity to bid on baskets full of goods donated by local businesses silent-auction style. Complimentary dinner catered by O’Toole’s and entertainment performed by James River students will be provided for guests as well.

Today is the last day to nominate your child's exceptional #oneCCPS principal for the R.E.B. Award for Distinguished Educational Leadership!

Stand-out principals:
· Promote excellence in education
· Demonstrate leadership and exemplify commitment
· Inspire students and advocate for their school and faculty
· Encourage team spirit
· Foster cooperation between the school and the community
· Maintain dialogue with students, parents, faculty, and staff

Each winner will receive a $15,000 grant - a $7,500 unrestricted cash grant to the principal and $7,500 for use of school-based initiatives of the recipient’s choosing.
(Nominations are due by 5 p.m. on Thursday, Nov. 7.)
Click here to nominate a phenomenal principal: bit.ly/REB_Awards_Leadership

Team Chesterfield:

Out of an abundance of caution given weather forecasts that call for strong storms tonight, all OUTDOOR activities involving Chesterfield County Public Schools after 6 p.m. are canceled.

Outdoor events, such as athletic and band practices, that start before 6 p.m. must be completed by 6 p.m.

Indoor activities will remain on as scheduled.

Thank you for your continued support!

What is your legacy? #oneCCPS seniors, Sophie and Kate, are implementing a plan to help better students' education within their own James River High School community. Their goal is to make a positive impact in the lives of their peers by narrowing the digital divide.

Thanks to community partnerships with Kajeet and Verizon Wireless, their vision is becoming a reality.

If you'd like to help them reach their goal, they will be hosting a
Digital Divide Silent Auction at James River High School on Thurs., Nov. 7 from 6-8 p.m.

For those who would like to donate but cannot attend the event, Sophie and Kate have created a GoFundMe page: http://gofundme.com/f/JRHS-hotspots :)

post_text: Everyone appreciates being recognized for going above and beyond! We love that Dr. D celebrates the great work happening across the county. 😊🏅 For more #oneCCPS behind the scenes initiatives and helpful family resources, go “like” and follow the CCPS Office of Family and Community Engagement.
shared_text:
CCPS Office of Family and Community Engagement
October 10, 2019 at 11:15 AM ·

On Engage Chesterfield we share information that links families and community partners to our schools. In this episode, we are going to share some “behind the scenes” incentives that have started for our school system employees. Everyone likes recognition for a job well done, and Chesterfield County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Mervin Daugherty acknowledges great work to the entire school system through his Game Changer Awards, Superintendent's Awards for Students, and will be celebrating retired staff members this year with the upcoming CCPS Hall of Fame.

Chesterfield County Public Schools #oneCCPS

post_text:
Today #oneCCPS students at Spring Run and Falling Creek elementary schools will participate in the Crunch Heard 'Round the Commonwealth as part of Farm to School Week! CCPS food and nutrition services will highlight locally grown fruits and veggies and offer apples to students from Carter Mountain Orchard. This program was created to help people recognize the importance of improving child nutrition, supporting local economies, and educating students about the origins of food.

Will you participate in the Crunch Heard 'Round the Commonwealth with them? These students would love to see that their good food choices are impacting others! Post a pic or video in the comments below of your apple crunch for us to share with them!

post_text:
We are so grateful for community partners like the Virginia Lottery! 🤞Thank you, Communities In Schools of Chesterfield, for always advocating for our #oneCCPS students! 📚

Friends of CCPS, if you haven’t already, go give the CIS of Chesterfield Facebook page a “like” to see the other great things they’re doing for our schools!
shared_text:
Communities In Schools of Chesterfield
October 8, 2019 at 12:05 PM ·

Awesome morning at Bellwood ES celebrating the donation of over 1,000 books through the Virginia Lottery! Literacy is essential to our students’ success and we are so grateful for their generosity and support! During the event, the Virginia Lottery also supplied breakfast and Pampered Teacher kits for the Bellwood staff! #thankyou #awesomepartners #weregameforeducation

post_text: Ever been to a book tasting? These #oneCCPS students got to sample a variety of nonfiction texts. Unfortunately, their waitress messed up a few orders and put some fiction books on their plates. Students had to "send it back to the kitchen" by explaining why it didn't belong!

post_text:
Don't forget! #oneCCPS is hosting a free event for parents of students with disabilities on Oct 7. Breakout sessions are available on several topics including:

- Tips and Tricks for Successful SOL Autism IEP Planning
- Elementary School Transition (for life)
- Experience Dysgraphia: Write or Left and Write with Mirrors
- Resource Team Meet and Greet
- Structured Literacy Simulations- Elementary and Secondary
- Making your IEP Count
- Organizing Your Student
- Growth Mindset for Parents
- Recognizing Children's Gifts
- Autism in Our Community

Parents may choose the sessions they'd like to attend, but space is limited.
Register here to save your spot: bit.ly/DestinationLife

post_text: In case you missed it, this year's first performance at the #oneCCPS Marching Band Exhibition was group piece that included all of the marching bands in the county! If you're looking for another opportunity to see several marching bands perform at one event, the 13th Annual Showcase of Bands will be on Saturday, Oct 19 at Midlothian High School. :)
